text.p: These are the leading stories in the Belgrade press on Friday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Bosnia will recognise Yugoslavia's continuity and Yugoslavia will respect Bosnia's integrity according to a statement signed in Paris by Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic and President of the Bosnain Presidency Alija Izetbegovic.
- Yugoslavia and France agree to step up bilateral economic cooperation during the meeting of Serbian president Slobodan Milosevic and French President Jacques Chirac.
- Serbian Prime Minister Mirko Marjanovic expects Serbia's development to bee more rapid after the lifting of sanctions.
- Average retail price growth in the January-September period was 47.2 percent in relation to December 1995, says Federal Statistics office. It does not expect annual inflation to exceed 60 percent.
- Trepca metals complex signed a $225 million deal over a three-year period with American firm Trafigura.
- Hungarian and Serbian police form joint expert group and agree to cooperate in combatting organised crime, drug trafficking and terrorism.
- Workers of Zastava arms from Kragujevac end six week strike.
- Yugoslav Foreign Minister Milan Milutinovic heads the list of the three party coalition -- Socialist party of Serbia (SPS), Yugoslav left (YUL) and New Democracy (ND) for the November 3 elections.
- Official exchange rate will remain stable as long as imports are financed with foreign currency stashed abroad and will start going up when this source is exhausted, analysis.
- Serbian trade ministry officially approves rise of milk prices from October 1.
- Belgrade fasihion fair to be held from October 8 to 11.
- We cannot expect spectacular improvements in Yugoslavia's economy after the lifting of sanctions, say economic experts.

- The road to getting back Yugoslavia's assets, blocked in almost fourty countries of the world while sanctions were in force, will be slow and gradual, says vice-governor of the National Bank of Yugoslavia Zarko Trbojevic.
